JOURNAL OF BIOSCIENCE AND BIOENGINEERING
Vol. 87, No. 2, 184-188. 1999

docTitle.titlePart:
Screening for Yeasts Incorporating the Exogenous Eicosapentaenoic
and Docosahexaenoic Acids from Crude Fish Oil

byline.docAuthor:
XU GUO, TAKAKO TOMONAGA, YUMI YANAGIHARA,
AND YASUHIDE OTA*

byline.affiliation: Department of Applied Biochemistry, Faculty of Applied Biological Science, Hiroshima University,

front.div:
The screening for yeasts incorporating exogenous eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid
@HA) into their cellular lipids was conducted. Two percent of oil from fish scraps was added to a yeast isolation
medium as a sole carbon source. From 143 soil samples, we isolated 23 yeast strains, nine of them were found
to be capable of quickly assimilating the scrap fish oil. These nine strains, in addition to four previously isolated
triglyceride-assimilating and lipase-producing strains, Yarrowia lipolytica and three Geotrichum species
(FO274A, F0347-2 and F04OlB), were cultured in a growth medium at 30Â°C. Strains F0726A, F0765A and
F0347-2 were selected on the basis of dry cell weight production and ability to store EPA and DHA in their cells,
and their performance was further compared by varying cultivation temperature and time. From 1 g of the scrap
fish oil, F0726A yielded 620 mg of dry cells, containing 47.1% lipid, 38.1% triglyceride, 3.3% EPA, and 4.9%
DHA, when cultured at 2S'C for 36 h. Strain F0726A apparently has the highest ability to incorporate EPA and
DHA into its cellular lipids. Results from further experiments showed that the incorporated EPA and DHA
mainly existed in the form of triglyceride in the F0726A cell. These results suggest that F0726A is suitable for
the production of cell mass rich in EPA and DHA for feed.
